content:
Posted: December 28, 2014
												Don't get me wrong, there are things about this game which are really quite excellent.  I really like the crafting system, and the companions.  The best part by far is the Neverwinter Gateway - a website you can log into to run new crafting missions, and play a dice game which is actually kinda fun to level your companions, earn rewards, etc...Aside from that though, the combat is a little boring, you have access to numerous skills, but can only ever have a few of them que'ed as active.  The zones are relatively small and linear, limiting your options and forcing you to play the way the devs want you to play.And as you have read in numerous other reviews, this isn't really a free-to-play game, if you want to enjoy it (and have all the best toys) you have to spend money, lots of it.It should be noted I didn't stick around for the end game, it just wasn't that interesting to make me think it was worth the time.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2014
												Game by Cryptic and Perfect World. It's an interesting game with a lot of intensive roleplay options, along with even more interesting monsters to kill and some interesting dialog to be read.I got to level 60, but prior was already analyzing what the game really was about in terms of trade, chat, PvE/P content activity, etc. What I was looking for exactly is:Is there an LG? (Level Gap - Means there's an area where you will run into less then 5 players.)Is it open world?Do people take up on self made content? (Professions, LFW [Looking for Work], roleplay, guilds/clans, etc.)PvP and it's aspects. (Is there a way to lone wolf and how can you conqueror at it.)PvE and aspects. (Are quests dragging on, npc voice acting, npcs and pathing + activity)How is the auction house? (Is it controlled by a select guild[s] or people, what is sold, LG?)Can I avoid the Item Mall?While Neverwinter is a pretty beautiful looking game there's no doubt, but it's locked a set FoV to make sure you think that. No, there is not a zoom in/out option so you have to type in a command to actually change your FoV. Worst of all is in the game you will see a lot of failed rendering and getting close to textures even on the maxed out settings...Shamefully blurry. Looks gorgeous at a distance, one they LOCKED down to make sure of that. If it's not failed rendering, it's bad glitches..From getting stuck in walls, not being able to use the /killme (/stuck) command to simply watching npcs run right through objects and hit you from triple the distance you can hit them at. By no means am I a PvP all star, it's not my forte. Am I bad, not really, it's just something I see constantly being destroyed and generic. Neverwinter is no exception somberly. While the modes for PvP are extremely generic like Domination, the actual combat is much more interesting untill you realize the other team is in full PvP gear, and you're not. The difference amount in such is staggering. I have and never will believe in PvP power and resilience gear, it's stupid, unfair and incredibly hindering for new PvPers. Pathetically to say, this game can claim skill as much as it wants you will not be able to kill a person in full PvP gear even if it was 1 vs 10. That's how different PvP gear is to PvE.As for PvE, it's just unfulfilling in my eyes. There was this level 18 - 22 zone I was in, and it gave me an option like Diablo and FPS Bots; Easy, Medium, Hard, Elite. I picked Elite because it sounded like fun, and for me to be fighting Battle-tested Orcs, Fire Wizard Orcs both elites, and giant Ogres plus the 10-15 normal archers and melee mobs...Happy is an understatement. I had to use skill to kill off the multiple Ogres and Elites and it was just too much entertainment. Pathetically, this isn't an option for every zone you enter. Frankly if there's no challenge, why play? I've played MMOs for over a decade, it's a reality for me, maybe not others.Now let's go back to my list, and don't worry this is much shorter and sweet.Questions & Answers:Is there an LG? (Level Gap - Means there's an area where you will run into less then 5 players.)>There's not much a level gap, 60s seem to be more then willing to help you out if they're not busy and you'll notice the dungeons really aren't hard at all. In fact they're very easy so long as you kill the major ones that can spawn mobs and heal.Is it open world?>It's not open world. It's battlezoned with one and only one major city. Which is f***ing pathetic in my eyes.Do people take up on self made content? (Professions, LFW [Looking for Work], roleplay, guilds/clans, etc.)>I can't be too sure yet if people really go into professions, I've yet to see weapons or armor for sale. No one is ever LFWing, as for roleplay, good luck. Doesn't exist at all from what I've seen. As for guilds, I'm not sure if anyone is even ever recruitting but that could just because the gold seller bots never stop. I mean never. You block one and two pop up within two minutes. This isn't a joke I've f***ing timed it. Two hours straight. They never missed a second. What worries me is I'd see a lot of legit names that players would have like "GrimReaper" etc. and it makes me wonder if account hacking is a problem!PvP and it's aspects. (Is there a way to lone wolf and how can you conqueror at it.)>Yeah, you can lone wolf it pretty easily. "Skill" + PvP gear... = 1 v 5 me bro lol u nub ded..... /♥♥♥♥INGSIGHPvE and aspects. (Are quests dragging on, npc voice acting, npcs and pathing + activity)>PvE has nothing special, some voice acting is good and the rest is to be questioned of drug use. Quests though are ridiculous and drag on as though to say "We couldn't think of anything else." I'd rather go kill x mobs and get y and z items then deal with a single quest that gives 2,000 exp and drags on for 5 hours. Not to mention you'll get voice acting in some NPCs, then suddenly it's gone. F*** off. What's worse is the Epic Dungeons are nothing more then the same dungeons you went through from 1-59 but now the mobs are level 60+. There is litteraly no other change.How is the auction house? (Is it controlled by a select guild[s] or people, what is sold, LG?)>Auction house seems...dead? There's items there for people at and under level 60 and even 20..But nothing good at all. Yet I've seen level 20-30s walking around in nearly full epics. I've never seen an epic yet and I've done nothing but grind quests and dungeons. I really don't know, at least not for levels lower then 60.Can I avoid the Item Mall?>No. Impossible. Unless you only want ever 2 level 60 characters, you will end up buying items from the Zen market. This is a 100% guarantee, and even if you think it isn't, this is a Zen market game in other words you can exchange an ingame currency (Astral Diamons [AD]) for Zen. And you will do it. I promise you, and with how expensive level 60 gear is in AD, it's a lot better for you to just buy Zen then it is to farm AD. That's your choice.For those wondering, no end game gear as far as I can tell is not ahrd to get at all. I have two days played now on my Trickster Rogue, I'm already worked into Tier 2 Epics with a gear score of 10,000 (About half the assumed max.) People take the pay-to-win route a lot and you will see it heavily, but you can make it without. It's just not as easy, and very, very annoying.Do I like this game? No. Would I recommend it? No..It's too easy to level in and too generic. Nothing stands out at all, even their target and combat system has been done and much better.

content:
Posted: August 2, 2015
												Firstly, I must state that I haven't paid any money for this game so I can't comment on pay-to-win problems.- Anyway, this game had a good atmosphere and a well written story. It wasn't surprising, considering it was based on Forgotten Realms.- But it also had -still has- a very active combat system, unless like a lot of MMOs with static ones.- Leveling up was pretty fun, too. "Not grinding" was the main reason for this, you always changed maps and quests and moved forward. It was very fun.These three properties made Neverwinter special in my opinion. But Elemental Evil changed two of these for the worse, much worse.Compared to the first 60 levels, it's story is really poorly written. It's like they didn't even bother to delve into massive sea of lore that is Forgotten Realms, but instead they made bad guys suddenly just pop up and attack us. That's it, there's nothing more to than that (except for an old friend, well technically two). No satisfying explanation, diologue or anything, they just attack and we just kill.Also, I was very confused and upset to see Neverwinter using the grinding system, especially in a game that was never meant to be that way. Using the same old maps, and very boring, not diverse quest types made it worse.Two of the most important things that made Neverwinter different from other MMOs were anti-grinding and story. And they somehow managed to ruin this.

content:
Posted: February 23, 2014
												When you first start playing Neverwinter you're kind of taken aback at the vast world and deep storyline in front of you. You roll a few different character classes like you would in any MMO just to play around. It is at this point that you finally see Neverwinter's greatest flaw. Redundency. Every class feels like it plays exactly the same. Every dungeon run, even with different people plays exactly the same. In order to get any of the currency you need for trading on the auction house, or if you want to trade for paid currency, you have to play the same redundent dailys over and over again. Most MMOs don't really start to feel redundent until late game but Neverwinter seems to accomplish that after level ten. I really really wanted to like it, as I said before the story was quite good, and the character created quests seemed interesting but Neverwinter just gets bogged down by it's own redundency. If you want to play it with one charcter and stick to that one character all the way till max level just to experience the story that could be an okay experience. Venturing beyond that and trying to play the game as an MMO instead of a single player game and the "magic" of game starts to truly fall apart.

content:
Posted: March 5, 2014
												This would be a very nice game if it wasn't full of bugs, most of them very frustrating. Example: you finish a dungeon or skirmish and you can't get the reward chest because you are still in combat with some glitching add that you just can't see. I played a lot of MMORPGs and RPGs and had my share of bugs with each of them, but when it occurs as often as in Neverwinter, it makes you feel sorry about all the time wasted playing the game. I never met a game so bugged as this one and I understand this problem has been going on for years now. I never got an answer to the issues I made notices for from no GM, even after weeks after I posted them.Conclusion? Although I understand it's a free-to-play game, the developer shows no respect to players however, therefore maybe they shouldn't be in the business after all.Too bad, this game could really have potential.

content:
Posted: January 31, 2015
												The game looks nice, the combat is very fun and engaging.  It's definitely a different take on MMO combat compared to other games I've played.  The character builds seem to have variety and depth, but I can't say for certain as I'm not max level.Unfortunately, that's where the good stops.The game is garbage.  You get nickel and dimed every two minutes.  If you want to succeed in the game you have to participate in the worst MMO activity ever invented - dailies.  Alternatively, cash shop.Beyond that, the rest of the game sucks as well.  It's extremely linear.  It is not open world.  There are ? and !'s above people's heads.  The group combat is faceroll.  Literally.  Play a healer, go to dungeon, roll face on keyboard.  Bet no one dies and nobody even notices that you didn't do anything.  The quests are boring and your actions do not affect the world in anyway.  There is no PvP outside of instances as far as I can tell.  The game is literally 95% PvE, even moreso than WoW.The game would be far better if it was subscription base not f2p.  Unfortunately, beyond the combat mechanics, the rest of the game sucks so I wouldn't subscribe anyways.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 5, 2016
												I loved the style of the game, I loved how there isn't a mana pool, I've only played one class which was the mage and I didn't reach end-game but I played a decent amount of the content, it's all very standard of an mmorpg and pretty nice stuff, interface can be a little confusing at the start (for example it took me a while to find out how to queue up for dungeons and stuff) but unfortunately as other people have said it is definitely pay2win and they constantly try to encourage you to buy things with real money by making every single mob have a pretty high chance of dropping these boxes, which they tease you with by showing you the epic loot inside, and they can only be unlocked with keys that as far as I'm aware can only be bought with an ingame currency called Zen which you can either buy or buy from other players with other ingame currency called Astral Diamonds which you can only get a certain amount of each day, I suppose this in essence stops "gold farming" situations however the economy is so skewed that grinding for the Zen Market items is unrealistic so you're practically forced into spending money, similarly to the boxes you're constantly given discount coupons which once again tempt you into spending money, you can't do anything else with them and dropping them brings up a warning like you're about to throw away the offer of a lifetime. The profession system from what I saw of it seemed intriguing although I never got into it deep enough to discover it's practicality, the unique thing about it is you're not locked into one or two professions but can train all of them to max level, however you're restricted, to level a profession you have to do "tasks" tasks are simple; have the required items, wait a set amount of time, receive reward, you can start the tasks anywhere and continue doing other stuff, however, at the start you're only allowed 1 task slot and professions seem to level painfully slow, additional slots can be unlocked once certain requirements are met but these requirements are clearly end-game level stuff and realistically it's still probably more beneficial to level up 1 profession first which will unlock you additional task slots, the game seems very grind intensive which I suppose can be expected in this day and age and I've heard some stories about the developers and tech support not being particularly caring towards their community, because of this and the fact that I feel they're just out to get your money I can't recommend this game completely, consider this a half recommendation, I suggest you download it and play it with a couple friends but don't invest too much of your time in it and don't invest any of your money in it, basically play it to check it out, especially if you've played other Neverwinter games because I felt like the combat mechanics were quite satisfying to start off with although the novelty wore off and the graphics are nice, a bit WoW-esque but I like that style.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 21, 2014
												My main complaint with this game is how simple the combat is. You have an 3 abilities on cooldowns bound to Q,E,R,  two "daily" abilities which you can use after attacking enough enemies, an artifact which may or may not be combat related and has a long cooldown, and then two normal attacks you use whenever by clicking left or right mouse. I'm not asking for something like WoW where abilities cloud up the bottom of your screen, but having access to 7 or 8 skills at a time gets real samey, and no encounter really differentiates itself as a result. There's a pattern to every fight I'm in, and it is Q, R, right mouse, then left mouse until I can use Q or R again, using a daily if there's a particularly tough enemy, and E if I need to heal me or my companion. I could spice things up and use R first instead of Q, but that ultimately doesn't change anything. At first this game sucked me in, and I loved the world, the music, the questing, all of it, but the combat was  too dull for me to continue playing (at least without friends, but practically every game is fun with friends.)

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 3, 2015
												This was the game that finally convinced me to close my account across all of Perfect World Entertainment's games. Firstly,  as a compulsive RPG hoarder, you start of with a very spartan amount of storage space for the many items you'll pick up and sell along the way. Half of the time I was playing, it was staring at the screen when it was telling me that my inventory was full. You'll get another bag at later levels, but it only provides around 12 spaces of inventory. I thought, "Hey, that's no problem. Maybe I can start crafting my own bags!" Nope. You get what you get, unless you want to pay real money. It also has some very imbalanced-feeling PvP, where you're steamrolling one team and getting destroyed by the next. Nearly everything in the game has its natural progression blocked to a dead stop until you a. find some way to farm the correct currency or b. pay up. I would like to support companies that make good content and give me very good reason to pay for premium features, but when the first thing you see is advertisements for ingame stuff that you would end up paying real money for, and a distractingly shiny "pay me!" logo in the interface itself, that's where I have to draw the line.

content:
Posted: July 26, 2015
												I'll keep this short, since all I really wanted to do is drop off a thumbs down.Pretty  much everything that people say about mod 6 is true. The grindfest for the endgame is already unbearable if you are an old-timer (like me) with 10 characters as profession farms. If you just started the game you will rue the day you hit lvl 65-70, unless you have a few hundred $$ to spare on this game.Prior to endgame the content is actually still fun, (as long as you avoid pvp), especially if you level through foundry quests. Don't get serious with this game until they fix the mess of mod 6 though.Edit: Ever since cryptic changed the AD economy things have gotten a wee bit better, if you are a casual player. The grindfest that is level 68 however still remains, and the refining systems to upgrade your gear is so painfully slow and expensive that you can spend more than half a year on one character's minute upgrades, while you repeat the same dungeons and daily quests, day after day.

content:
Posted: July 26, 2015
												The game started out great, but exploits surfacing every few months makes the game very unfair when it comes to PvP. A new player will have to spend several thousand dollars just to compete, and even then the class-balance and patches are horrible for the most part. If you want to try it for the story and gameplay go ahead, but I suggest you stop playing after you have hit max level because from there on it is all a cash-grab where you either exploit or pay to stay competitive.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 10, 2015
												I found this game through Steam but played mostly without Steam.I have two lvl70 chars, a Scourge Warlock, the first one, and the Oathbound Paladin, my main char now.At first this game felt amazing. Beautiful graphics (I turn off Post Processing and Bloom because I don't like the result, performance is amazing here even at 2560x1440 with everything maxed out), lots of customizations and classes, races, quests, refinements, wow. A lot to discover and try, so a lot of fun.After a while I found I was stuck, or the progress was slowing down a lot, and the main cause was clear: unless spending real money I could never have enough to keep progressing. Ok, that may be fair, but by spending money in this game I mean A LOT OF money. Everything is crazy expensive and you gotta have in mind that if you spend a lot of effort, time and money creating a char, your class will probably be nerfed to useless so you'll lose it all without warning. That's how they make money here. It's pay to win, it's expensive and they will kill your char so you need to play and spend over and over again.When I was geared enough to try the content to better geared chars, the game turned into a complete mess. We have, for example, Valindra's Tower, Malabog's Castle and Epic Lair of Lostmauth. You need to wait in a queue to get in any of those. Sometimes you wait for 30 minutes, 40 minutes, or even more. And when you can go in, lag lag lag. By lag, I really really mean it. You start to rubberband a lot, timewarp a lot, key commands take 1 to 2 seconds to work. I listed Valindra's Tower, Malabog's Castle and Epic Lair of Lostmauth. After maybe two months doing quests while waiting to enter these, the first two were absolutely unplayable with most players simply leaving due to the lag. I coundn't finish the first two due to that. The Epic Lair of Lostmauth I finished only once, and when I did, the prize, a chest for you to open and pick your rewards was bugged and I couldn't take anything. So I tried again and again over and over (I really needed the armor and due to the lag I could't foresee any other chance to get it), maybe 20 tries or more, and finally it worked. I recorded a video showing this.Well, after playing for a while and playing A LOT everyday, I ended only logging in to do some daily quests to advance in the campaigns. My chars are stuck because I'm not putting any money on this game because it feels like they may change important things anytime; because I can't play very important parts of the game, the most difficult and rewarding ones, due to lag and bugs; because paying is the only way to succed here. And you need to spend a lot.Note that I don't even mention PVP. PVP in this game is the most stupid thing I ever seen.EDIT: I forgot to say that my first char was abandoned because it was a god until lvl60 but after that turned into suffering and frustration, dying all the time to anything that moves. I kept playing with it until after the lvl70 (and two or three excess lvls so I have many skills maxed out) but the char kept dying over and over again, too weak for anything. I tried different gear, different combination of stats, maxing defense, maxing deflection, maxing power, arpen, crit, making it balanced, nothing worked. Then I read the class was intentionally nerfed. Should have researched first.Then I created the OP and even before the lvl70, when I was like lvl67, I was destroying everything the first char couldn't even face. The difference is HUGE. I can leave this char afk in the same places where the first char can't even walk in alone. This game is unbalanced like hell.

I kept playing with it until after the lvl70 (and two or three excess lvls so I have many skills maxed out) but the char kept dying over and over again, too weak for anything. I tried different gear, different combination of stats, maxing defense, maxing deflection, maxing power, arpen, crit, making it balanced, nothing worked. Then I read the class was intentionally nerfed. Should have researched first.Then I created the OP and even before the lvl70, when I was like lvl67, I was destroying everything the first char couldn't even face. The difference is HUGE. I can leave this char afk in the same places where the first char can't even walk in alone. This game is unbalanced like hell.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 27, 2014
												Pros: The combat in the game is really fun, its not your tipical click and wait MMO. It feels more like an action adventure game, where position and dodging is key to survive.Cons: A) BUUUUUUGSSSSSSS: The game was launched as a full game on june 2013, so you´ll think the game is in a playable state, yet the VERY FIRST DUNGEON in the game was bugged and to my knowledge to this day its still bugged and it cant be completed and the fourt dungeon you can access was also bugged and couldnt be completed. I understand that MMO may have bugs and glitches after release, but after a year, having your VERY FIRST DUNGEON IN THE GAME BUGGED IS UNACCEPTABLE....also crashes, falling through the map, dungeon bosses who wont drop any loot, etcB) The time you spend leveling from 1 to 60 is the most repetitive process i have ever seen in an mmo. You start in a city, you get a quest to teleport to a certain area, you go there, accept a bunch of quest that involve either killing X amount of enemies or gather X amount of materials, you complete them and then you get 1 more quest that asks you to go to a unique instance and fight a mini boss, you go back to the quest giver who tells you to go to a different quest giver in a different part of the area, once you get there is the same thing...5 to 7 quest and then a miniboss, you do this 3 times before you are sent back to the city to go to a different area....AND THIS HAPPENS IN EVERY AREA, 5-7 quest, mini boss, do this 3 times and you are done with that areaC) Even though you can be a f2p without a problem, from lvl 1 to 60, everything in the game is hiden behind a paywall. Like any other MMO by perfect world enterteinment, the game has 3 different kinds of currency1)Bronze, silver and gold coins: Classic mmo currency, that is basically useless, since the things you can buy with it are limited to potions, 1 single mount (a horse that comes in 6 differnet colors) and very low lvl gear.2)Astral diamonds: Unique currency in the game that can be obtained by doing daily quest or by doing certain profession tasks. This is the most usefull currency in the game and so the hardest to get. You can use it to buy high lvl gear (you can pretty much avoid the dungeon grinding for gear at lvl 60 and buy a whole set of gear using diamonds) The auction house items can ONLY be bought with astral diamonds, unique mounts, cosmetics, basically everything that you cant buy with the previous currency must be bought with astral diamonds, especially the most important item in the game...the scroll of identification, that are used to idenfity gear so you can see the stats and wear it and since enemies have a higher chance of dropping gear than scrolls you are going to end up with a bag full of green or blue items that you cant wear because you dont have scrolls.3) Zen: The universal currency of everysingle perfect world entertainment game, can only be bought with real-life money and you can use it to buy more astral daimonds or other items like keys used to open lockboxes or the most basic feature of every mmo out there...resseting your character stats in case you made a mistake, yep, you can only "respec" your character if you pay real money...thankfully there is an in-game feature that allows real players to offer zen for astral diamonds, so you can grind astral diamonds and buy zen without spending any money...but since the people who buy zen are the ones who put a price, the amount of diamonds needed for a decent amount of zen is astronomical.Now you may think thats not a big deal since that doesnt necessary means the game is pay to win....well think again, you can actually see videos online of people soloing dungeons in the game because they bought high-level gear or special items like scrolls that allow you to resurrect the moment you are killed so the bosses health wont reset.


YouTube™ Video: Castle Neverwinter - Last Boss Azharzel - Rogue Solo 

			Views: 19,221		

			Last boss of neverwinter, getting solod by a trickster rogue while we watch. He used about 30 rez scrolls, Pay to win for sure. build based on 4 set pvp bonus and stacking recovery.		

  <---- a perfect example of what i´m talking about

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 20, 2014
												Model (F2P): The biggest downside to the game is its Zen system which, I suppose is the only way for a free MMO to make money, as one would expect from a F2P model. Unlike in games like Path of Exile, the items purchased with Zen can definitely be game altering and offer advantages that free players would not have access to at a much earlier level. However, there is a way to convert in game currency (Astral Diamonds) into Zen at a conversion rate that changes depending on the market. Neverwinter sometimes pushes the player to use special currencies in order to open lockboxes containing level-appropriate equipment, but is otherwise not too intrusive. Unfortunately, the in-game currency of Zen-to-Dollar ratio uses an extremely expensive conversion when compared to other F2P games such as Rift. While most decent item sets cost somewhere between 1500-3000 zen, approximately 500 zen = $5, depending on how many Zen are purchased at once.Gameplay: Some of the most innovative and fun combat you'll find in the current MMO scene. The classes are very well fleshed-out, but definitely not balanced as of yet. Most classes require re-positioning, timing, and anticipation when reacting to enemies or even allies' actions. It's definitely not a click and spam blindly game. Unique mechanics are introduced depending on the class. A Guardian Fighter can hold up a shield to block attacks, while a Rogue can quickly close distance with a teleporting strike. Every class feels truly unique and full of flavor. The combat system is mostly based on a D&D-type of ruleset with skilltrees in the form of feats and eventual specialization. While questing is very linear and everything else is pretty much what you would expect in a standard MMO, the profession system is more of a que-and-wait.  Overall I would recommend this game to anyone who's awaiting WildStar and its combat system and wants something similar to satisfy their hunger for ARPG-type combat. Additionally, creative minds can use this game to create scenario-type quests and dungeons through a feature I personally have not used much called the Foundry.Multiplayer: Standard faire for the current MMO market. PVP scenarios of varying types pitting 5v5, co-op challenges that can quickly be completed with friends or random players, and dungeons. Lots of variety for all types of players and a guild system. Most players use the in-game chat to find groups or members. No innovation, but definitely satisfying for those who don't like soloing.7.5/10

content:
Posted: June 24, 2014
												The game is amazing and accomplishes everything it tried to do to make an MMORPG interactive, story-based and action-based. Although I am not one which enjoys questing, the quests in this game are amazing, and creating a new character to experience the questline again is enjoyable and exciting. One thing I have learnt through experience is that this game is perhaps the opposite of Pay2Win. I did not believe that when I started playing but experience and time in this game are what counts the most. My only reason to stop playing this game was that the end-game storylines and quests are extremely repetitive, and after you own 4 level 60 characters with maxed out epic tier items for PvP and PvE, the game is pretty much done, and you feel that the game is definately over. I reccomend this game to anyone into serious and difficult MMOs, in which you can show your skill in either PvE or PvP. You will be rewarded in either way. I assure at least 200 hours of excellent game-time before any symptoms of boredom towards the game show up. I myself have played over 230 hours of it and finally bored myself over the end-game quests. But don`t take my word for it. Try it yourself. Perhaps you are more of a quester than me.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 15, 2014
												It's free-to-play, very full-featured, and a ton of fun if you like fantasy MMOs. Uses the Dungeons & Dragons 4th Edition rules, which actually work a lot better as a computer game than they do in the pen & paper game. The combat is surprsingly robust, much more interactive than in a typical MMO - it uses reticule targeting rather than Tab targeting, and that's a LOT more interesting. The big bonus is the built-in Foundry editor which allows any user to create their own quests, so there's a huge amount of user generated content, some of it very good indeed.Overall, it's currently my go-to MMO, and I recommend it highly.

content:
Posted: November 21, 2015
												A game that starts strong but collapses into a world where you're forced to dance along a drum line of serrated drill-bit sex toys that continually penetrate your ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ while you beg for forgiveness. You'll pray to "wake up," but then the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ will chant "can't wake up" as they gnaw at your colon from the inside.PROS---Combat gameplay is fluid, vicious, and fun as hell. I can only speak from experience as a single-target DPS trickster rogue, but the glee I felt from stealthing-and-stabbing never faded even as enemies' hit points rose.---Leveling from 1-60, for me, averaged about 45 minutes per rank. I wasn't rushing to cap, either, and while I admit my eyes glazed over the quest text halfway through the storyline, I wasn't sprinting. Fast, but not too fast.---Events, skirmishes, and dungeons are great breaks from regular questing, though having to pay for chest keys (with in-game currency or with IRL munz) after the once-per-day free one is lame. I get it though: a company has to make money somehow, which is why this stays under positive.---Professions can all be leveled and no progress is lost (there's no swapping out mechanic--they're all available all the time).---The auction house is totally open for F2P players.---Minsc and Boo for us elderly BG players to get a nostalgiagiggle from. NEUTRAL---Quests from 1-60 are relatively-basic MMO trash, but I never got bored because of how brutal the combat was.---It's not an open-world game, but the above-ground instances are large enough to require mounts.---Sparkling lines and the linear nature of most of the world means you'll never get lost.CONS---The 60-70 grind is absolute garbage. There are no scripted/plotted quests; instead, all you get are repeatable hourlies set in a couple different areas that give tiny chunks of XP. Grind in MMOs is fine. This is like being bound in leather straps and lowered♥♥♥♥♥first onto a chainsaw of OhMiBods made out of shark teeth. It doesn't sound so bad reading it here, but in-game, after having so much fun from 1-60, it's like taking your supermodel date home from dinner and finding out instead of a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ she has a black hole that leads directly into Satan's urethra. ---All of the endgame level 60 content from previous patches has been shifted to level 70, leaving the hourlies as the only content to carry the ten longest and most difficult ranks in the game. WHY.---The paid DLC is hilariously overpriced.---Loads of the in-game tooltips have outdated text, as well as the official wiki and the Neverwinter website. Aren't there interns for this? Or fan volunteers? ---There seems to be no effort to combat spammers and farmers. I get a new friend request every five minutes from someone wanting to trade or sell me something. My inbox is always full of spam as well. It doesn't sound that bad, but when you're kiting for your life and some prick sends you a request it gets annoying.---The "need, greed, pass" popups in dungeons and skirmishes are virtually in the middle of the screen. And there's always that one nub♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥who feels the need to pick up every green item he sees, which forces the prompts to stack, literally filling the screen with them. WHY.---Because there are no traditional gathering nodes (all resources are collected from enemies and occasional, randomized nodes that require kits to interact with), I can't unleash my inner hoarding and trading personality. I won't really hold this one against Neverwinter, though, because I imagine it's to combat ♥♥♥♥tarded BR farmers. Still, annoying.SUMMARYIt's free. You technically can get all the stuff from the premium shop with in-game munz. The 1-60 process was a blast. But from then on it's a completely-different grind that's totally not worth your time. Find a different game until they add something to make those ten levels more entertaining. (And no, it's not "my problem" that they're insufferable. The ten hardest levels in the game shouldn't be less fun than getting my bum waxed in preparation for my date with @Nero. They should be the MOST fun, with deference for perhaps the FIRST ten.)Drizzt was a nice touch with the new mod, but still, his stuff is locked out at the 70 cap. Have fun with that.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 2, 2015
												Good GameGood GraphicsPoor Managment/DevelopersThe game graphics are good, the play style can be very fun, but the developers are so far behind the curve for MMO's its sad, they're barely implementing concepts common to MMO's now in their 8th Mod/expansion in 2 years.  I've been playing since July 2015, and it's extremely easy to level characters to play End-Game content, but so repetitive when you finally get to the end-game content that you want to start another character just to enjoy something different to break the monotony.And they've finally figured out that the best way to make money is to essentially force players to buy most everything via ZEN  which is predominantly purchased with Real World Money.. because they've created numerous mechanisms e.g. Bound to Account BoA and Bound to Character BoC items that you are guarenteed to have inventory issues requiring buying Bank Slots(ZEN)  buying Bags (ZEN).  Other mechanisms that require ZEN are the Astral Diamond Exchange (Astral Diamond - AD) an in-game currency; which like most every MMO, they've made so many mistakes creating an economy for, that people exploited the hell out of it.. and made massive piles of AD  making the exchange market a joke for any peron who wasn't either exploiting it or buying it with Real World Money.The next way to soak up your time and money is in the form of Artifacts; Artifacts are weapons and equipment that are mostly End-game items, there are numerous artifacts you can have from around level 20, but the weapons and equipment will not be avaialbale till a player reaches level 70(Max level)  and can only be upgraded with Refining Stones and a few other very Minor things like lvl 60+ weapons, and considering it will take so many of these items that the people making money on refining stones and refinment items is split about 70/30  Exploiters-Botters/Cryptic  the exploiters run mass amounts of bots farming anything they can sell on the Astral Diamond exchange and Cryptic expects you to buy most everything else from them to actualy complete and finish refining an item to make it more powerful.Other than Cryptic's lame claim that they are trying to make the game playable for people "with time to play" and people "with money to play" they are very definitely focused on soaking money from people in the latter category.The most annoying thing beyond the money grab is that the game has so many glitches and development screw-ups that if you enjoy playing all of the content and reading all of the stories and background.. you may miss a whole lot, because they've broken nearly every Dungeon that isn't part of End-Game content and if you level too fast or power level you will not be able to go back and finish any of it, because they're too focused on keeping up the End-game content and keeping people paying that they're avoiding fixing the lower level dungeons.  The easy fix has been in most every other MMO i've played,  You power leveled past some stuff, so you join with a group of people to play that older content and your overall level etc is reduced back to the level of the content.  But 5+ mods/expansion later and they're still ignoring that massive gaping hole --that DnD fans like the content and the story--, which most DnD fans I know would/should be pi$$ed about.My biggest gripe isnt that they want to make a proifit, you cant keep a good genre MMO alive without money, but that they are ruining the DnD name with they're inept development and managment of a great Genre of MMO.

content:
Posted: February 20, 2016
												It's Crash to Desktop:  The game.  I hear this game is great, so I give it a shot.  Two hours downloading patches later I try to start it only for it to die on the loading screen.  Repeatedly.  Dozens of forums and advice pages of people who have the same problem later I tried all the tips.  I tried the "don't start in full screen" the "start in safe mode" the "start in Windows 7 compatability" and even the "open this folder, right click on that and enter this random string of digits into the line here."  None of it works.  I know I am not the only person who has these problems (see:  dozens of pages of other people that have the same problem) , yet Cryptic doesn't seem to care. The download is free.  The game is, apparently, quite good.  If you can play it.  So if you have a few hours to spend trying a game that may not run go ahead.  Maybe it will work for you.  Me, I'm uninstalling this piece of crap.

content:
Posted: June 3, 2014
												I am actually not certain whether to recommend this game or not.  It is entertaining in many ways.  However, I played Neverwinter since the beta and many bugs still exist after approximately one year of release (and several patches--which focused on the zen market most of the time).  The inadequate class balancing makes it frustrating for those who love PVP (only specific classes are worth taking into PVP).  If you have played Dungeons & Dragons PnP style, you will find that this game is not entirely D&D (I believe it is stated in the game description that they used modified 4e rules).  If you are looking for something closer to real D&D, Dungeons & Dragons Online is the way to go.  Unfortunately, something about DDO that seems to fail to grasp my interest for a longer duration.  On the other hand, I found myself playing Neverwinter only to collect diamonds during my daily invocation and whenever there is an event.  I think the Foundry is its main asset for now.  As a former Dungeon Master, I wish I have the time to invest in creating quests in the Foundry.  I would like to recommend this game because it is somewhat enjoyable to play.  However, I just find it hard to recommend at this point because of issues that the developers should have fixed a long time ago (graphics bugs, game launcher crashing every so often, game patching can be buggy to some people, some dungeons are frustrating to run because of bugs, some quests/areas/dungeons become buggy right after patching--sometimes to the point of getting stuck and not be able to proceed or appropriate loot not dropping, highly expensive items in the market, and more).  If Steam had the option to take the middle ground, I would have picked it because the game is not a horrible game.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 11, 2015
												It's difficult for me to classify Neverwinter as an MMO. I feel a much better description would be a dungeon hack-and-slash with some MMO trappings. Character customization is bare bones, even leaving out the fact that certain iconic races are locked away behind the pay wall. You're able to choose your character's sex, race, and class along with his/her origin and patron deity. The latter two are surprisingly limited, given the setting; even in 4th Edition's greatly reduced pantheon, there are a number of gods and goddesses worshipped by the people of Faerun, yet the game only gives you a fraction. Likewise, the origins only cover a handful of locales in the Realms. It quickly becomes apparent that this game was not made for diehard fans of Forgotten Realms.If you're looking for a worthy successor to Neverwinter Nights, you will not find it in this game. The Foundry is a poor substitute for that legendary series' robust world-building and DM tools, with even the most highly regarded player-created dungeons essentially boiling down to the same formulaic hack-and-slash gameplay of the main game. I cannot recommend this game to anyone looking for a meaningful MMO experience. With a friend or two, some fun can be had in  fighting your way through waves of kobolds and orcs so long as you keep your expectations in check.Overall: Pass

content:
Posted: October 14, 2015
												TL;DR - if you are into D&D you'll probably try this game anyway, and you should. for a reader there is some satisfaction in running around the areas you read about. this review is more of a personal disappointment of failed expectations strictly from gaming perspective. ---dont' mind the low hour qty i have listed on steam.i was one of the original founder packs supporters and spent nearly a year playing the game, spending about ~600 across different packages and booster packs. early quests are OKAY. they look like at least a little bit of thought was put into them. however, relatively quickly it becomes mindless grind. you can completey not pay any attention and fight and level very easily. on occasion you come across inept objects and maps portions that seem like the authors were still attempting to do something interesting, but then got distracted by the money making and gave up.i came from DDO, and apparently ive been taking it for granted how great the stories were behind the quests and how stimulating it was to solve some of teh puzzles, and traverse the diverse environemnts, including under water. every "map" in Neverwinter just feels like a slightly different layout of the same thing. so do, in fact the classes. Fury of the Feywild gets slightly refreshing, but not by much.2 saving graces of the game are PvP which almost feels like FPS with the right type of people, and The Foundry, where people with actual writing talent can create some interesting quests for you to play out side of the main story line. if you do play the game, dont bother with any of the $$ packs. they do not enhance the game play at all. they just serve as shortcut to getting to the next level of boredom so you dont spend more time on your lower level of boredom. I gave this game another shot on steam hoping it would at least allow for some trivial achievements, or collector cards. that does not exist either. worse, the game play appears to have become even more grindy. the stats math appears to have been redone and i was artificially struggling in maps that i usually breezed through. the same effect can be achieved by playing maps ahead of year level number. it doesnt save the game play.

content:
Posted: January 18, 2014
												Strangely enough, the PC based version from years back in the 90's gave you a better experience, closer to your character.  The inability to zoom in close, to either have a 1st-person point of view, or a very close third-person view, breaks the immersion for me in this type of game.  If I wanted the diablo-esk birds-eye-view, I would have played diablo.  I played several characters for a bit to try and give it a decent run, but the inability to get close to my character had me exiting out and uninstalling before too long.  Nice concept on a stellar dinasty of a gameline, but did not deliver.  Seems more of a WoW graphics with  Diablo viewpoint, with random short-term central bazaar style game system.  It's a no from me, sorry.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 19, 2014
												Neverwinter Nights and Neverwinter Nights 2 were beautiful games. This is not a beautiful game. This isn't even a beautiful MMO. Disapointment doesn't even begin to describe my feelings in realizing that there will never be another installment of Neverwinter Nights, and Neverwinter will only exist in the pretend gaming comunities that are modern MMOs. If you want to see a desperate gambit to get money by mutilating the Neverwinter setting then this is the game for you. This game had potential for being good, but a few fundamental mistakes were made. First and foremost, it was designed to be another MMO in an endless sea of MMOs (Thanks Blizzard). Second, the game tried to integrate pay2win and grind2win without ever considering the previous titles did well because they were play2win. Thirdly and lastly, the company tried to push a game that the returning demographic would not only be disinterested in playing, but also be offended that something they loved was turned into something so heckneyed and low quality. The last mistake might not have been so bad, but their only real advertisement was through Wizards of The Coast, a company that caters to users that would share the woes of the returning demographic.TL:DR, Game is bad and Perfect World Entertainment should feel bad.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 2, 2014
												Another F2P MMORPG out of many that you can find on Steam. And another one from Cryptek. This one attempts to mix it with beat-em-up, and in some parts it does, but you can still tell away that it's MMORPG with auto-targeting things. They just hid old combat style of MMOs, made it look cool.And it does seem to have enjoyable cool feel to combat, but only for first few hours. With all fancy no-mana, dodging and all usual stuff, with only few skills being easily activated from the HUD, ha. Sure thing no one wants such things with grinding and long leveling, when you can just play much more fun designed single-player beat-em-ups. After all, it's all just run from one group of enemies to another, repeat and grind. It's also heavily instanced MMO, sending you to one quite often. Quite linear in exploration too. Has one of those systems where you can party up with randoms to be send into special mission dungeon. PvP isn't shining either. At least one thing Neverwinter have over Champions Online (Cryptek's another MMO) is that bosses don't ignore every single stun skill that players can use on enemies.This one takes D&D setting, and it takes it in such way that as a person that isn't into that setting, I found nothing intersting compared to other generic fantazy.It also lacks customization, it's all "you wear what you have equiped" and are still restricted by class system. Quite is kinda shameful, especially seeing how one of previous games of Cryptek had one of more the most awesome character skills and look customization.Bright side? The Foundry, mission editor. You can't make core mechanic more intersting with it, but you can come up with more interesting plotline and share it with players.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 3, 2014
												This surprised me, for a f2p its not bad.    Pros: PvE this is where the game shines.  There's different  queues for dungeons and skirmishes (team up with people to defeat an outdoor mini dungeon) for your level range.  There's also the foundry which has thousands of player made content which is always being updated and keeps things fresh.  You can of course create a foundry mission which the community can play and applies to the previous statement.  Cons: The classes have balancing issues in pvp and if people have better gear than  you then you'll get rolled but if you farm enough you can get the same gear but its mildly pay to win.  There's class issues in PvE as well for instance I played a tank (so  called) which would lead you to believe you would tank, hold aggro, and be a damage sponge.  This is not the case.  You spend most of your time  running out of the red spots as a tank, which means you aren't dps'ing, which means you're not generating enough threat to hold aggro.  If you stand  in the red and don't block you take huge damage...as a fully geared tank, and spec'ed full tank (I tried both the tank trees in full defensive gear 51% dmg reduction, 32% parry which is very high, and 15% aoe reduction, a large hp pool, among other things) you take massive damage.Your only hope is to use your aoe taunt which has a long cooldown, and spam your fighters recovery daily which unless you're tactician you wont have up when you  need it so thats the  only viable spec I've found.  The so called cookie cutter spec is to stack attack power and go down the tree  that gives you double attack power if you have full block (which means if you block your dps is lowered based on how much shield you have remaining).  This is great for threat, but you can't take much damage and the healing in  this game is pretty bad imo.  This saddens me as I only had an interest in tanking in NW and they've failed the class.  Tanks aren't taken most of the time end game, people would rather have ranged and cc ( ranger and control wizard) control means no healing and more aoe damage potential.Until they fix the tank class to be able to actually tank I wont be playing the game.  ============================================================I did create a foundry mission which was very time consuming (you can spend as much or as little time as you wish on a foundry mission) as I chose to build my own multi-story building (very limited tools made this a lot harder than  it needed to be, for example, if you could select more than one object to copy / paste, it  would have saved me days of work if not more).The community can rate your foundry mission in a 5 star system if they play it and for the most part the community in the foundry is good.  But since most people don't create foundry missions, they don't appreciate how long it takes to make them.  If you want an example do a search for my foundry mission "Ghost - behind enemy lines" and play it.  That foundry took me over 3 weeks to make and I'm out of work so that means every day I was working on it (most of the time was building the last building).Its not all bad though, I went into the foundry  sort of knowing it would take a while and some people would be unappreciative but for the most  part the reviews were friendly and the comments some people had were very  satisfying and thoughtful.  People can donate astral diamonds to you if they wish and a lot of people do so that's nice.  If the community rates it high enough it can be hosted by the devs.   People play your content and enjoy it, that makes you feel like you wrote a novel (which you actually are an author in this case) and people like it, this makes it worth it.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 20, 2016
												Graphics look like they're from the late '90s, even on the max settings, and the combat feels antiquated. Why play this when you could shell out a small amount and play a more modern MMO like Black Desert Online, etc, or one with a stronger developer like WoW? The only thing going for this game is that it's F2P to start, but you'll quickly realize you'll have to spend a bit for a reasonable experience. This is basically WoW-lite.

content:
Posted: April 4, 2015
												Neverwinter for PC is an outstanding MMORPG from what I have experienced. I have not gotten to a maximum level yet, and I'm not a Neverwinter expert, but based off of my 22.9-hour-impression,  I highly reccomend this game for anybody looking for an MMORPG.Pros:-free to play (all levels for everyone, features like being in a party open to everyone, etc) -good graphics-lots of useful video settings-proper third person view (moving the mouse to turn character)-default controls are simple and open to edit-useful guidance to locations for quests (sparkling line, not pointing arrow)-most things in the game do not require real money-slightly automatic aiming, useful if you're a bad aimer or using a gamepadCons:-not compatible with gamepads / console controllers (although it will work if you use your own installed key binding program)-mounts (creatures that you may ride on) must be purchased with the zen currency which is difficult to get unless you buy it with real money-a couple of races require an expansion pack that you must pay real money forIMO (In My Opinion):-better than any MMORPG I've played-very fun

content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
												I'd say it's one of the better free to play games out there, but with that being said, there are some faults with it. Since it is a F2P MMO, there is obviosly going to be a microtransactions store. However, I wouldn't exactly say that it is pay to win.With the aiming and casting mechanics, early game is fast paced and fun. The only problem I have with this game is the end-game. After reaching the max level, everything becomes a daily quest. You log in, do the quests, claim your reward, maybe replay your favorite dungeons, and then get off. It becomes tedious and boring after a while.If you're looking for a casual MMO to get into where you don't have to farm for hours on end, give this game a try.

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 7, 2016
												This game makes me so frustrated.  It has pros and cons, and if tended to could be so much better for players and producers. After playing various characters reaching endgame this is my conclusion-->PVE - Amazing tho a bit linear, still has good stories and quests compared to allot of other grinds out there.  I enjoyed many of the zones and contrary to many critics on vioce acting I didn't find it too bad.  Which is hardwork considering it's f2p.  Combat is fun and fast paced (not too easy, not to hard) and allows for some room to make character builds.  And if you have friends to play with and choose not to pay money to climb this game could be very extensive on PvE terms.  The foundry is one of the best aspects of the game.  It doesn't take a computer science degree to understand the fundamentals to allow for campaign creation. (However it does go down quite often which is unfortunate)PVP - *sigh*  This is the most damaging aspect of the game.  It has the potential to be great but anyone who plays who has not sunked 1k real money into will admit - "Is broken"  Unbalanced and pure p2w.  Literally post upon post will say the same thing without a change.  Unless pvp is fixed the competetive fan base will dwindle like a candle as it is already and continue until gone.   But in overall opinion it is a fair f2p game but has the potential to be one of the best if handled better.

												As a long-time player of the Neverwinter Nights series, this game practically screamed my name to play. I would pay big bucks to play an amazing game like this, and it is even more so amazing that it is free. 10/10 already one of my favorite games of all time!

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 18, 2015
												Hands down one of the best free MMOs I have ever played.  The game is not the most gorgeous, but it looks good.  The game is not incredibly complex, but it has an intricate balance.  I really enjoyed my time in the game... and even outside of it.The dynamic of playing the game from a browser with my companions is brilliant.  The fact that I can craft from the same browser is amazing!  If they had an app that did something similar, I'd almost pay a small monthly fee for it.  The companion system by itself is actually pretty awesome.  Someone to hang out with you and support or tank or fill whatever gap you have is pretty awesome.  While some of them could stand to be a little better, they are pretty good overall and the ones at the beginning of the game are very helpful. My favorite part, however, is the user created content.  The ability to run a "dungeon" created by another player is amazing.  I've run some good ones and bad ones, but that feature is awesome!  When I say dungeon, it does it a bit of dis-service.  It is more like an entire zone built with encounters, buildings, bosses and loot tables that plays out as a full quest or mission.  Some of them can be done in 10 or 20 minutes, while others may take more than hour.  The difficulty is also variable.The micro-transactions for this game can get pricey, but I didn't worry too much about them.  They have some interesting packs and people who plan to invest a lot of time can easily wait until a sale and get a great deal.  IMO, the game is good enough to at least invest a little bit.

number of helpful: 6 of 10 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 27, 2014
												I have been seeing a lot of negative reviews saying the game is pay to win. If you are going to try out the game, know one thing: you will not start to make a good amount of AD, the main currency, until you hit the max level (60). The game's economy is mostly based around the player base and player market. Items that you get from endgame dungeons will either be worth 500 AD or 500,000 AD depending on how badly the buyer wants said item. For instance, I earned a piece of armor a few days ago that sold for 600,000, but today it is worth around 150,000. You may also exchange AD for the premium currency, Zen, which you have the option to pay actually money for. The only thing you can not get in game without paying actually money are the packs which are really not a big deal.      This is my most played game on steam and I personally think it is very underrated. The questing can feel a bit grindy but it is almost fully voice acted. There is also great deal of lore is case you want to get into it. Otherwise the combat is very quick and responsive, the loot and customization is executed very well, and I feel the game should have a much bigger playerbase.

content:
Posted: February 25, 2014
												This game is SOOOOOOOO ADDICTING... Ive played so many mmorpgs but i usually end up quiting cuz of the long, boring and endless hours of grinding. However this game is always action packed with the large amount of bosses/dungeons. You level up quickly from following the main quests so it keeps gamers from getting bored of doing the same thing. Dungeons also get SUPER epic when you have a full party of 5 especially when you get later into the game. (level 45+)Graphics are amazing at full HD quality, character customization is awesome (get to choose races, jobs etc), combat system is great (similar to Tera Rising)-- dodge/block system, PVP is fun (kinda like capture the flag or Dominion in League of Legends), overall game can be competitive (mechanically skilled players can outplay other players with op stuff), and much more.I reached the max level 60, and during that experience it was HELLA FUN! And it gets way better cuz once you hit 60, you get bombarded with more crazy quests and you can customize your character even more with the access to boons (another skill tree). Overall I HIGHLY RECOMMEND THIS GAME! It's just amazing bcuz you can have the same amount of fun by yourself or by grabbing some of your buddies to do the dungeons/quests with.10/10

number of helpful: 9 of 16 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 6, 2013
												As someone who has played other D&D games before, but has not played the pen & paper game, Neverwinter felt very accessible. It has the most enjoyable combat out of any MMOs that I have played to date.As a free-to-play game, it has a real money (referred to as Zen) cash shop. While all of the items in the cash shop seem expensive, I never felt like I was required to purchase any of them to enjoy the content that everyone else was playing. As you play, you can earn the in-game currency, Astral Diamonds, and exchange it with other players for the Zen that they have purchased. Depending on what you are looking to purchase, the length of the grind required varies dramatically.As for content, the Foundry and its "infinite content" is a nice distraction from the developer made quest line. Some of the quests that players have created are absolutely ridiculous, both in personality and in quality.I highly recommend giving Neverwinter a shot and forming your own decision. It doesn't take that long to reach the level cap, and it's free - what do you have to lose?

number of helpful: 10 of 18 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 16, 2015
												Is it the best F2P mmorpg out there? The short answer is no. There are a lot of things that are a problem, and most of these centre around the business model of the devs. That being said it is still entirely possible to enjoy yourself if you are looking for a drop in/drop out online exp. The vast majority of the negative reviews are born out of the gaming communities disgust at having to spend actual money on a game they are playing for free. Let that sentence roll around for a moment. Very simply it boils down to whether or not you are looking for a suitable end game experience. If you have a lot of money to burn then this is the game for you. If, however, you would like everything to be free in this world (I think someone once said some about the price of a lunch...) then this is not for you. If you, like me, are just looking for a casual and beautiful online experience to jump into every now and again, then I would say go for it. After all, it is free.

number of helpful: 14 of 26 people (54%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 6, 2016
												I've jumped around through several "Free" MMORPGs.  Thus far, I've found Neverwinter Online to be the most fun. The combat is reactive and skill can matter as much as the skills you choose. I know that a lot of people have cut the game down for being "pay to win", but if you are not out to be the most dominate player in the game with all the best gear (right away anyway) then you will have fun.Pro: LOTS of quests with varied objectives.     *Decent community compared to many games. Get in a guild and you will have a lot of fun.     *Good respawn times for MOBs. Not a lot of waiting around.     *You can play casually OR delve into the depth of the game's crafting system.Cons: *The graphics are standard. Not bad, but mostly not going to impress seasoned players. Some nuances ,such as mounts, look very nice though.      *It can be considered pay to win. If you are one of those who really think "winning" is possible in an MMO, then you may not like this one.    *The HUD is weak, but can be customized to your liking.There's a lot more to be said about this game, but the bottom line is that it is fun for casual players who fear getting involved in the time-sink that is typically associated with MMOs

number of helpful: 11 of 20 people (55%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 17, 2014
												A F2P game with some elements of nickle and diming but they're avoidable. It's totally playable without putting a cent into it but you're restricted to two characters. There's no restrictions on the gameplay itself and it's quick to level to 60.     Resetting your character's active skills costs "Zen" which is real money, but you shouldn't have to unless you've been playing level 60 for a while. Resetting passive skills called "Feats" cost ingame currency called "Astral Diamonds" and it scales depending on how much points you put into it already. Astral diamonds can be traded for Zen and vise versa to help cover costs for an extra character or a skill reset if you're worried about spending real money, but it takes time to collect enough of.    Unfortunately, the economy is somewhat bloated with bot farmers selling ingame currency for real money, causing some items on the market to be ungodly amount of astral diamonds to buy. Finding a party to get into a dungeon is almost impossible unless you advertise yourself on the "Looking For Group" chat or bring friends. One of the classes, The Devoted Cleric, has a high difficulty curve that can surprise new players and is not recommended to play during your first time unless you know what you're in for. There's also balance issues with enchantments and high level pvp which the developers said to be patched soon.     All in all, decent free MMO that if you don't have problems with gambling (see TF2 or CS:GO i.e crates), should really only cost you none to 15 USD. Surpisingly fun and the classes feel great and powerful to play. It's recommended, if it is your first time, to just play the game however you want without worrying what build you should spec into.

number of helpful: 86 of 168 people (51%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 5, 2013
												I have been playing neverwinter since beta, and I can say I enjoy the game. The story is interesting the gameplay is fun the graphics are smooth and the setting is just great. There are not many things I have found fault in with neverwinter but some of these are as follows, for an mmo neverwinter feels extremely linear with one quest linking to the next all the way to endgame. Another thing I dont like is endgame, I always get bored but this seems to just be the mmo way atm, there content creator helps somewhat in that user generated content can be pretty great, but it does not completely make up for some of the default content lacking that spark that makes it interesting. Even another thing that rubs me the wrong way is pvp, when the game was a newer release there seemed to be a more active pvp scene but now all the matches seem to me unbalanced and boring. Now dont think for a second I am going to end the recommendation on a sour note, I had a LOT of fun with the game on all my characters up until the point you start to feel that inevitable mmo fatigue. I recommend you try the game yourself to see if you like it or not, yea end game can be grindy, yea there are some ridiculous cash shop items but are these not things we have all come to expect from a free to play mmo? The game has a lot to offer and a lot of fun you can experience without paying a dime or grinding a second, so get out there and get playing!Update 7/30/14: Neverwinter fans rejoice, Neverwinter is coming to xbox and its getting a new expansion!Update 8/11/15: Neverwinter just keeps getting new content. I have not played in a while but this is good news. I hear its one of the most popular free to play games on Xbox now as well!

number of helpful: 11 of 20 people (55%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 6, 2013
												Although PWI/Cryptic have developed a (well earned...) reputation for nickel-and-diming players, Neverwinter is a surprisingly competent and fun action-RPG "MMO" (its really more small group focused and never feels like a massive world). The game is heavily instanced and much more fun in groups, much like actual Dungeons and Dragons would be. Don't go in expecting a sequel to Neverwinter Nights and you'll have a much better time. The Forge is fun to mess around in too, and some of the player-created missions are cool (there's a clever Wizard of Oz inspired one that I enjoyed).

number of helpful: 25 of 48 people (52%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 15, 2014
												Oh where to begin with Neverwinter. Now this review will most likely bring on a lot of controversy, but who cares.Neverwinter is a f2p MMORPG Published by Perfect World. Now a lot of Perfect World games tend to be "Pay to Win" to the extreme. Neverwinter is not pay to win unlike the others. The only thing to win in Neverwinter is PVP, but PVP isn't a big part of the game itself and there are no items you can pay real life money for to help you in PVP. Of course Neverwinter has an in-game currency called "Zen" that you can pay real life money for, but the only thing Zen lets you buy are "Fashion Items", dyes, companions, mounts, and a few other items not essential to own. Now of course like many other MMOs, in game currencies like Zen can allow you to pay for convenience such as buying a fast mount. Mounts serve no purpose other than getting you where you need to go at a quicker rate rather than walking. Is that Pay to Win? NO, it is not. What are you winning? A race to the quest area? People do not like spending real life money on MMOs, but the game is free is it not? So complaining is silly. Anways, the main currency in Neverwinter (that requires no real life money to earn) is called "Astral Diamonds". You don't want to spend real life money on Neverwinter? Have no fear, with AD you can purchase companions, mounts, and plenty of other neat items. Though for a price. 25k AD is the max you can earn with your daily quests, however, every dungeon you play you have a 90% chance of obtaining a "Purple" item. Purple items sell for a fair amount of AD on the auction house whether its to 20k or 1Mill. So really, earning AD is not an issue. Me? I've played Neverwinter since Beta two years ago and have never spent a dime to get the cool items I desired. I just played the game and earned AD, which as stated before, isn't as hard as people say it to be. The point of playing a game is earning what you want and working towards your goal. But many are lazy and do not want to work for what they want. I also forgot to mention, if you really want something off the Zen market but have no desire to pay real life money for exclusive items on it, did you know you can trade AD for Zen? Isn't that nice that Neverwinter allows you to do that? They give you every option in the game to get what you want without paying a single cent. I don't know about you, but thats very nice, especially for a FREE game. In game events also happen often, and every event gives you a chance to get a very unique item of some kind whether its so a very cool fast mount, a strong companion, or just a silly item like a portable throne! Now lets talk about the workers behind Neverwinter that are really a great group of people. They constantly work hard daily to keep Neverwinter running, adding new content very often, and keeping it bug free. The employees are also very easy to get ahold of and they are the most helpful bunch that will assist you with anything you need. Its very important for a game to have that. They also play Neverwinter, and they even take the time to play with players in-game and occasionally help out people in need. How cool is that? They also Stream on Twitch often and give away in game items and even phsyical items like T-Shirts. So overall, Neverwinter is one of the best free to play MMOs out right now. There's a reason I've been playing this game since beta. It even has an epic story line unlike many other MMOs that don't. Like everybody else, I skip dialog, I don't care, I just want to play. With Neverwinter, everything about it whether its to the lore or story line, is so very intriguing and makes you want to really understand whats going on and pay attention. Neverwinter is also very visually stunning and the amount of work and detail put into this game is really quite amazing. Don't believe me? Check out my screenshots and look at my Neverwinter ones. You'll also see that I have an epic mount, easily obtained by earning AD.Like MMORPGs? Want a game full of endless content you can spend countless hours on? Do you like Dungeons and Dragons? Then take the time to play Neverwinter ♥

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 15, 2014
												First of all this is not a pay to win game. ZEN is a currency you can buy with real money. You can convert ZEN into Astral Diamonds or do the opposite - AD into ZEN. AD can be achieved by doing daily quests and is the trading currency used in the Auction House and several merchants. You can buy ZEN to quicken your progression or make the game more convenient(e.g. extra inventory slots, respec tokens, rare companions and more). ZEN converted into AD can get you rare and powerful items from the Auction House. Only difference a paying user could have, is if he bought a Starter pack or Guardian of Neverwinter pack and he would receive exclusive gear, mounts/companions, enchants. They barely affect gameplay and only have vanity value, rather than becoming stronger. All content is the same either you're a paying user or a free user, it depends on how much are you willing to grind. You can grind to get AD and then trade it for something you want. Or be a bit more patient and do daily quests and sell unwanted stuff in the Auction house.Proffessions are a grind fest and work based of timers. You need a certain leveled/valued worker, reagents and time. Most proffesions have task times of 10-60minutes. Leadership on the other hand has 2-12hours. You can access proffesions from your browser/mobile device so if you're really determined you can progress in proffesions nicely.Neverwinter is worth a try, for a free-to-play mmo this one is indeed special.
